user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of shmem_child:
```c
static void *shmem_child(void *arg)
{
	const char *name = arg;
	struct {
		metal_mutex_t	mutex;
		int			counter;
	} *virt;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	unsigned long phys;
	size_t size = 1 * 1024 * 1024;
	int error;

	error = metal_shmem_open(name, size, &io);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed shmem_open: %d.\n", error);
		atomic_fetch_add(&nb_err, 1);
		return NULL;
	}

	virt = metal_io_virt(io, 0);
	phys = metal_io_phys(io, 0);
	if (phys != METAL_BAD_OFFSET) {
		if (virt != metal_io_phys_to_virt(io, phys)) {
			atomic_fetch_add(&nb_err, 1);
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed virt != phys.\n");
		}
		if (phys != metal_io_virt_to_phys(io, virt)) {
			atomic_fetch_add(&nb_err, 1);
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed phys != virt.\n");
		}
	}

	metal_io_finish(io);
	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function shmem_child:
int metal_shmem_open(const char *name, size_t size,
		     struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	struct metal_page_size *ps;
	int fd, error;

	error = metal_shmem_open_generic(name, size, result);
	if (!error)
		return error;

	error = metal_open(name, 1);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to open shmem file :%s\n", name);
		return error;
	}
	fd = error;

	/* Iterate through page sizes in decreasing order. */
	metal_for_each_page_size_down(ps) {
		if (ps->page_size > 2 * size)
			continue;
		error = metal_shmem_try_map(ps, fd, size, result);
		if (!error)
			break;
	}

	close(fd);
	return error;
}
...
static atomic_int nb_err = ATOMIC_VAR_INIT(0)
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
#define METAL_BAD_OFFSET ((unsignedlong)-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in the provided code fragments.
- In shmem_child(void *arg): arg is only read and copied into a local pointer (const char *name = arg;). The parameter variable arg itself is not assigned to or changed anywhere in the function. Objects pointed to via other pointers (e.g., io, virt) are used/returned, but no parameter is modified.
- In metal_shmem_open(const char *name, size_t size, struct metal_io_region **result): parameters are only passed to other functions and used in expressions. The function does not assign to its parameter variables (there is no statement like name = ..., size = ..., or result = ...). Assigning to *result (i.e. storing the returned pointer into the object pointed to by result) is allowed by Rule 17.8 (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). The code here only passes result to other routines or uses it for returning the mapped region; it does not modify the parameter variable itself.
- Other uses (atomic_fetch_add(&nb_err, 1), metal_log, comparisons with METAL_BAD_OFFSET, local variable assignments like fd = error) do not modify any function parameter.

Note: bodies of called functions (metal_shmem_open_generic, metal_shmem_try_map, metal_io_* functions) are not provided. If those functions (in their own definitions) assign to their own parameter variables, that would be a violation in their implementations, but that is outside the provided code. Based on the supplied code, there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8, so no suspicious fragments are reported.
